questions.text: Which serotype of HPV is responsible for carcinoma cervix?
questions.solution:
HPV serotypes 16, 18, 31, 33, 35, 39, 45, 52, 56, 58, 59, 68 are associated with carcinoma cervix.

Risk factors for carcinoma cervix include:

  • Human Papilloma virus (most important)
  • Sexual intercourse before 18 years
  • Multiple sexual partners
  • Multiparity
  • Poor personal hygiene
  • Smoking and drug abuse
  • Women with STD, HIV, HSV 
  • Immune suppression

Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) or southern blot or Hybrid capture technique is used for HPV DNA detection.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding HPV?

choices.text: E1 and E2 are viral proteins needed for replication
E6 and E7 are viral proteins needed for malignant transformation
E6 acts via the retinoblastoma gene
HPV 16 is the most common serotype causing carcinoma cervix

questions.solution:
E6 acts via the tumor suppression gene p53. It increases proteasome-dependent p53 degradation. E7 binds and acts via the retinoblastoma (Rb) gene. 

The viral E6 and E7 oncoproteins encoded by the high-risk type HPVs (such as HPV 16 and HPV 18) are necessary for malignant transformation. 

E1 and E2 oncoproteins are responsible for viral replication.

questions.text: Which is the HPV serotype most commonly associated with carcinoma cervix?
questions.solution:
HPV 16 is the most common type associated with carcinoma cervix.

Associations between human papilloma virus (HPV) serotypes and carcinoma cervix:

  • Most common serotype - HPV 16
  • Most malignant serotype - HPV 18
  • Most specific serotype - HPV 18
  • Most common serotype associated with
    • Squamous cell carcinoma - HPV 16
    • Adenocarcinoma - HPV 18

Cancers caused by HPV:

  • Male - penile, oral, anal
  • Female - cervix, vagina, vulva

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient comes with repeated infections of trichomonas vaginitis, her physician advises for a Pap smear. She asks you regarding the purpose of this test. What would be your appropriate response?

choices.text: It is a screening test for cervical cancer
It is a diagnostic test for trichomonas infection
It helps to diagnose cancer in her genital tract
It helps to diagnose other associated genital infections in her

questions.solution:
A pap smear is a screening test for cervical cancer. It is not a diagnostic test (option C). The presence of abnormal cells/ a positive test requires further evaluation by colposcopy, cervical biopsy, or fractional curettage. 

If trichomonas is reported from Pap testing, it should be confirmed by saline microscopic preparation (option B). 

Cervical cancer screening should start at age 21. Women aged 21-29 should have a Pap smear every 3 years, while women aged 30-65 should have both HPV and Pap co-test every 5 years. Women should stop having cervical cancer screening after the age of 65 years. If suspicious PAP, screening till 75 years. HIV+ women should have annual checkups until three consecutive negative tests followed by testing every 3 years for life.

Pap testing should be done prior to vaginal examination. Lubricants should not be used and the patient should not be menstruating during the pap test. The patient should not have intercourse 24hrs prior to the test. The ideal time is around ovulation. 

Procedure:

  • The patient is put in a dorsal position, and the labia are parted
  • Cusco’s self-retaining speculum is introduced
  • The squamocolumnar junction is scraped with Ayer’s spatula:
    • Bifid end - ectocervical sample
    • Blunt end - vaginal cytology
  • Endocervix is scraped with a cytobrush
  • The sample is spread on a glass slide
  • The slide is immediately fixed using 95% ethyl alcohol
  • Stained with Papanicolau stain or short-duration Papanicolau stain (SPS).

Related Pearl: Management of CIN

questions.text: A 45-year-old lady complains of post-coital bleeding. She has a positive pap smear. What is the next line of management?
questions.solution:
The appropriate management of a 45-year-old with a positive pap smear and post-coital bleeding is a colposcopy-directed biopsy.

A per speculum examination must be done whenever a female comes with post-coital bleeding in order to evaluate for carcinoma of the cervix. If growth is visible, a punch biopsy should be done, and else if no growth is visible, then a pap smear is done. A pap smear is a screening test for cervical cancer. The presence of abnormal cells/ a positive test requires further evaluation by colposcopy, cervical biopsy, or fractional curettage.

Cervical cancer screening should start at age 21. Women aged 21-29 should have a pap smear every 3 years, while women aged 30-65 should have both HPV and pap co-test every 5 years. Women should stop having cervical cancer screening after the age of 65 years. If a pap smear is suspicious, then screening is continued till 75 years. HIV+ve women should have annual checkups until three consecutive negative tests followed by testing every 3 years for life.

Pap testing should be done prior to vaginal examination. Lubricants should not be used and the patient should not be menstruating during the pap test. The patient should not have intercourse 24hrs prior to the test. The ideal time is around ovulation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old sex worker presented with irregular menses, post-coital bleeding, and occasional foul-smelling vaginal discharge. She was advised to undergo a Pap smear. What is the best time for this investigation?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of cervical carcinoma. The best time to do a Pap smear is around ovulation, but it can be performed at any other time as well.

Prerequisites of doing a Pap smear:

  • It should be done prior to vaginal examination
  • Lubricants should not be used
  • The patient should not be menstruating during the pap test
  • The ideal time is around ovulation
  • The patient should not have intercourse 24hrs prior to the test.

Based on Pap smear findings, dysplasia of cervical cells is graded using various classification systems such as WHO grading, CIN grading, and the Bethesda system.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about Schiller's test?

choices.text: Lugol's iodine is used to paint the cervix
The epithelium is stained mahogany brown
It detects the presence of glycogen in the epithelium

questions.solution:
The abnormal cells remain unstained on performing Schiller's test.

Schiller's test, also known as VILI (visual inspection with Lugol's iodine), involves painting the cervix with Lugol's iodine. It is used to detect any abnormal cytology in the cervix and vagina, such as in cases of carcinoma cervix. 

The normal vaginal and cervical epithelium contains glycogen, therefore stains mahogany brown on being painted with Lugol's iodine. The abnormal cells remain unstained. These areas need to be biopsied and sent for histopathological examination.

questions.text: Which of the following would you not expect to see in the colposcopic biopsy of a patient with cervical intraepithelial neoplasia?
questions.solution:
The basement membrane is intact in cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN).

Features of CIN:

  • Varying degree of dysplasia
  • Altered nuclear-cytoplasmic (N:C) ratio
  • Hyperchromatic nuclei
  • Mitotic figures
  • Intact basement membrane.

questions.text: Which of the following methods is most commonly used for the treatment of CIN?

choices.text: Large loop excision of transformation zone

questions.solution:
Large loop excision of the transformation zone (LLETZ) is the most commonly used treatment option for cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN). It is also known as loop electrosurgical excision procedure (LEEP).

It is applicable for the treatment of CIN anywhere in the lower genital tract. This uses electric current through a monopolar wire electrode to either cut or coagulate cervical lesions. Like other excisional procedures, it is done in the immediate post menstrual phase.

The procedure involves minimal patient discomfort, cost, and complications. Since it can be performed using local anesthesia, it has become the primary outpatient treatment modality for high-grade cervical lesions.

Related Pearl: Management of CIN

questions.text: Which among the following is the treatment of choice when microinvasion of cervix neoplasia is suspected?
questions.solution:
Conization is the treatment of choice when microinvasion is suspected.

  • Indications of conization
    • Endocervical dysplasia
    • Transformation zone is not completely visualized
    • When there is discrepancy of findings between cytolology, colposcopy & biopsy
    • Microinvasion is suspected
  • Indications of hysterectomy
    • Older & parous women
    • Uterus is associated with fibroid, DUB, prolapsed
    • Recurrence or persistent lesion
    • In-situ adenocarcinoma cervix

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman has cervical intraepithelial neoplasia III. What would be the management?
questions.solution:
Colposcopy with LEEP would be appropriate management for CIN III.

Loop electrosurgical excision procedure (LEEP) is an opd procedure done under colposcopic view and local anesthesia.Here, a low voltage current is passed through the loop and a cone of tissue is removed from the cervix. This procedure causes minimal bleeding and the tissue removed is sent for histopathological examination (HPE). This is the treatment of choice for CIN 2&3 of any age and parity.

Related Pearl: Management of CIN

questions.text: Which is the most common malignancy in women in India?
questions.solution:
Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women in India as well as globally. Cervical cancer is the most common genital cancer in India.

Lip and oral cavity cancer is the most common malignancy in men.

Risk factors for carcinoma cervix include:

  • Human Papilloma virus (most important)
  • Sexual intercourse before 18 years
  • Multiple sexual partners
  • Multiparity
  • Poor personal hygiene
  • Smoking and drug abuse
  • Women with STD, HIV, HSV 
  • Immune suppression

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the transitional zone?

choices.text: Nabothian cysts mark the original site
It is limited to external os

questions.solution:
The transitional zone or squamocolumnar junction is well outside the external os during the reproductive period. 

It is the site where the squamous epithelium lining the vagina merges with the columnar epithelium of the endocervix. The original squamocolumnar junction is marked by the presence of Nabothian cysts and glandular openings.

It is a dynamic part and moves with age and hormonal influence:

  • During pregnancy and with oral contraceptives, it pouts out of os.
  • Following menopause, it gets indrawn inside the os.

The cells here are highly sensitive to irritants, mutagens and viral agents such as HPV. Cancer screening using Pap smear involves scraping this area and studying the cells for nuclear changes.

questions.text: Identify the false statement regarding adenocarcinoma of the cervix.

choices.text: Most common site is transformation zone
Cervical cancer is the second most common cancer among women in India

questions.solution:
The most common site of adenocarcinoma is endocervix.

It commonly occurs in young females and OCP users, and is associated with HPV 18.

questions.text: You would suspect and evaluate for carcinoma cervix in patients presenting with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Patients with carcinoma cervix most commonly present with metrorrhagia, now known as intermenstrual bleeding.

Post-coital bleeding is the most specific symptom of carcinoma cervix.

questions.text: What is the most common site of hematogenous metastasis of cervical cancer?
questions.solution:
The most common site of hematogenous metastasis of cervical cancer is the lung.

About 1-2% of patients with cervical carcinomas present with lung metastases, and 5-35% eventually develop lung metastases. 

Other common sites of blood-borne metastases include bone, liver and bowel.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman comes for follow-up a few months after surgery for carcinoma cervix. On evaluation, she is found to have a recurrence of the malignancy. Which of the following is true about her condition?

choices.text: Most common site of recurrence is pelvic lymph node
Mortality in patients with recurrence is due to pulmonary embolism
Treatment involves surgery with lymph node dissection
Recurrent tumor with largest diameter <3cm has good prognosis

questions.solution:
A recurrent tumor with the largest diameter of <3cm is associated with a good prognosis. 

The extent of recurrent disease and involvement of pelvic lymph nodes are prognostic factors for survival. An isolated central pelvic tumour with no involvement of the pelvic sidewall also has a good prognosis. 

Most recurrences are seen within 3 years and the prognosis is poor with uremia being the most common terminal event. Recurrences most commonly involve the pelvis than the para-aortic or pelvic lymph node.

All patients with a suspected recurrence should undergo PET/CT for evaluation and biopsy for confirmation.

Treatment involves either radical chemoradiation or pelvic exenteration. Concurrent chemotherapy with cisplatin and/or 5-fluorouracil may improve the outcome.

questions.text: Identify the true statement about the staging of cancer cervix.

choices.text: Clinical examination is the first step in staging
Tumor markers are important for diagnosis of metastasis
CT scan is the best method to assess principal tumors
MRI is the best method to assess nodal metastasis

questions.solution:
Clinical examination is the first step in staging carcinoma cervix.

Clinical examination was the principal method in staging until the 2018 FIGO guidelines which recommended the use of imaging and histological investigations when available. USG, CT, MRI, and PET-CT can be used to assess the extent of the tumor, nodal status, and local or systemic spread.

MRI is the best method to assess the principal tumor while PET-CT is the best method to assess nodal metastasis.

FIGO no longer mandates biochemical investigations, such as tumor markers, for diagnosis of metastasis.

Related Pearl: Staging of Carcinoma Cervix

Stage I - limited to the cervix

  • A: Microscopic lesion
    • A1 - stromal invasion <3mm depth
    • A2 - a stromal invasion of ≥3 and <5mm depth
  • B: Macroscopic lesion
    • B1 - stromal invasion ≥5mm depth & tumor size <2cm 
    • B2 - tumor size ≥2cm to <4cm 
    • B3 - tumor size ≥4cm 

Stage II - involves upper 2/3 of vagina

  • A: Extends to the upper two-thirds of the vagina without parametrial involvement
    • A1 - tumor size <4cm 
    • A2 - tumor size ≥4cm 
  • B: Extends to parametrium but not upto the pelvic wall.

Stage III - spreads to lower 1/3 of vagina

  • A: Extends to lower 1/3 of the vagina
  • B: Extends to the pelvic wall (hydronephrosis/non-functioning kidney)
  • C: Involvement of the pelvic and/or para-aortic lymph nodes, irrespective of the tumor size and extent
    • C1: pelvic lymph node involved
    • C2: para-aortic lymph node involved

Stage IV - metastasis

  • A: Bladder/bowel involvement (adjacent pelvic organs)
  • B: Distant metastasis

Note: The involvement of vascular/lymphatic spaces does not change the staging. The lateral extent of the lesion is no longer considered.

Stage IIIB is the most common stage of presentation.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presented to her gynecologist with postcoital bleeding. She was diagnosed with carcinoma cervix stage IB after evaluation. What is the treatment of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Type III hysterectomy is the treatment of choice in carcinoma cervix - stage IB. It involves radical hysterectomy with pelvic lymphadenectomy and para-aortic lymph node evaluation.

Stage IB is defined as a macroscopic lesion still confined to the cervix, with the depth of invasion ≥5mm. It is the first stage in which lesions become clinically visible.

Hysterectomy types include:

  • Type I - Simple / extrafascial
  • Type II - Modified radical / Wertheim
  • Type III - Radical / Meigs-Wertheim
  • Type IV - Extended radical Hysterectomy
  • Type V - Exenteration.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman is found to have a lesion in the cervix which is 7mm wide and has a depth of 4mm. She has one child and wishes to preserve fertility. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
The woman has stage I A2 cervical cancer and the most appropriate management is radical trachelectomy with pelvic lymphadenectomy.

Radical trachelectomy is a fertility-preserving surgical procedure. This involves the removal of the entire cervix and parametrium.

Cervical conization with laparoscopic or extraperitoneal pelvic lymphadenectomy is an alternative that also preserves fertility.

Note: The involvement of vascular/lymphatic spaces does not change the staging. The lateral extent of the lesion is no longer considered.

Stage IIIB is the most common stage of presentation.

questions.text:
Which among the following are contraindications for radiotherapy in carcinoma cervix?
  1. Pelvic inflammatory disease
  2. Vaginal stenosis
  3. Post-menopausal status
  4. Adenocarcinoma
  5. Associated prolapse
questions.solution:
Post-menopausal status is not a contraindication for radiotherapy in carcinoma cervix.

Contraindications for radiotherapy in carcinoma cervix include:

  • Pelvic inflammatory disease
  • Young patient (to preserve ovarian function)
  • Associated myoma, prolapse, ovarian tumor, genital fistula
  • Vaginal stenosis
  • Adenocarcinoma or adenosquamous carcinoma – surgery preferred.

questions.text: You are planning to administer radiotherapy to a 58-year-old woman diagnosed with carcinoma cervix. What is the dose to be administered at point B?
questions.solution:
In the treatment of carcinoma cervix, the dose to be administered at point B is 6000 cGy.
